keywords.keyword: Dolphin User's Guide - Package Browser - Binary Packages

para.text: Dolphin Developer's Guide - Deploying for the Web - Binary Packages

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Dolphin developers are used to the
mechanism as a means of partitioning their source code into easily manageable units. Packages can be exported from a developer's
and then later reloaded into the same, or different images. The standard package mechanism can be seen as a method of manipulating and distributing Smalltalk source code and
introduces the idea of a Binary Package for distributing the same functionality for applets but without having the overhead of distributing the Smalltalk source code at the same time. The

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: class is used to hold the contents of a normal source package but in binary only format.
